snippet: The Remington Financial Group offered clients help with financing but cheated many of them. Its founder was recently sentenced to 18 years in prison.
abstract: Alina Tugend Shortcuts column; second of two executives with Remington Financial Group, which offered clients help with financing but defrauded many of them, faces sentencing; firm's founder Andrew Bogdanoff, who pleaded guilty with five others, was sentenced to 18 years in prison; experts say shaky economy, job insecurity, tighter loan requirements from banks and need to supplement low incomes or pensions create perfect market for what is known as advance fee fraud.
lead_paragraph: The Remington Financial Group offered clients help with financing but cheated many of them. Its founder was recently sentenced to 18 years in prison.

headline.main: A Fraud Case Offers a Cautionary Tale of Finance
